author: Danny Shapiro
title: Cardinals defense on brink of complete game
text:
Cardinals defense on brink of complete game Danny   1:00 am, Friday, October 16, 2015 
Lamar defensive coordinator Craig McGallion is just looking for some consistency. 
At times this season, McGallion's defense has looked impenetrable, but other times they've looked like a unit playing together for the first time. 
It's a trend McGallion hopes ends Saturday when the Cardinals travels to face Northwestern State at 6 p.m. in Natchitoches. 
"It's definitely frustrating to the guys that we haven't been able to put together two complete halves," McGallion said. "But (a complete defensive game) is one of those things that will happen as we keep getting more mature." 
The Cardinals allowed 55 yards and forced a turnover as they jumped out to a 24-0 halftime lead against Abilene Christian a week ago. 
However, the second half was a different story as the Cardinals allowed 270 yards, 28 points and saw their lead trimmed to 34-21 at one point. 
Second half struggles haven't been uncommon for the Cardinals, who stymied the nation's highest-scoring team Sam Houston State in the first half of their conference opener, holding the Bearkats to 14 points en route to taking a 35-14 halftime lead. 
In the second half, the Bearkats struck for four touchdowns including three scoring drives that took less than two and a half minutes. 
"We always come out with the mindset that we need to dominate the first half," said Cardinals sophomore linebacker Shawn Jones , who leads the defense with 41 tackles (26 solos). "But we get complacent sometimes once we get a big lead. We get too relaxed." 
The Cardinals' defense has been working on becoming more consistent in practice this week, increasing the intensity to the point where defenders can only stop moving if they're granted a water break. 
Jones thinks because of that intensity and past results, Saturday's game against the winless Demons could provide the perfect chance for the Cardinals' defense to stay on track for four quarters. 
"I think we're right on the verge of having a complete game," Jones said. "We've been showing it in practice all week. I think this could be our coming out party." 
McGallion backed up Jones' confidence in the defense having a complete game, noting his approval for the practice intensity post-Abilene Christian. 
"Tuesday's practice was our best Tuesday practice of the year defensively," McGallion said. "We really practiced well." 
A complete defensive performance could prove to be the difference between a three-point win, like against the Bearkats, or a three-point loss and a spot in the FCS playoffs at the end of the season. 
"We've been able to stand up to teams at the end (of the game)," McGallion said. "So we're trying to take that and what we've done at times in the first half and make it a whole game thing for our guys."
